Description: Jugate busts of Ptolemy II, draped and diademed, and Arsinoe II, veiled, right; dotted border. (obverse)
Jugate busts of Ptolemy I, draped and diademed, and Berenice I, veiled, right; dotted border. (reverse)
State: Associated with: Kingdom of Egypt Ancient Greece and Rome: Kingdom of Egypt
Curator's comments: Walker & Higgs 2001 On this coin, the king has more prominent sideburns and the chin is closer to the portrait type of Ptolemy I. The shield behind his head may refer to a specific victory. The figure shown in profile beside him is his sister-queen, Arsinoe II. The new denomination, the 'mnaieon', with a value of 100 silver drachms, became the standard gold denomination in the Ptolemaic empire after the late 260s BC. These were the coins that Demetrius, of the famous Cairo papyrus, would have been producing at his mint (P.Cairo.Zen 59021).
Bibliographic references: Walker & Higgs 2001 / Cleopatra of Egypt: from History to Myth (68)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2009 11 Dec-2010 10 May, Madrid, Canal de Isabel II, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2009 1 May-20 Sep, Victoria, Royal BC Museum, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2007 14 Sep-2 Dec, Hong Kong Museum of Art, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2007 3 Feb-27 May, Taipei, National Palace Museum, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2006 18 Mar-4 Jun, Beijing, Capital Museum, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2005 27 Oct-2006 31 Jan, Haengso Museum, Keimyung University, Daegu, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2005 25 Jul-8 Oct, Busan Museum, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2005 11 Apr-10 Jul, Seoul Arts Centre, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2004 26 Jun-29 Aug, Niigata Bandaijima Art Museum, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2004 10 Apr-13 Jun, Fukuoka Art Museum, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2004 17 Jan-28 Mar, Kobe City Museum, Treasures of the World's Cultures 2003 18 Oct-14 Dec, Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum, Treasures of the World's Cultures
Associated names: Portrait of: Ptolemy I Soter I
Acquisition name: Bequeathed by: Sir Allen George Clark
